column1: RIT is well on its way to developing the leading performing arts program in the nation for non-majors::: attracting talented and creative students who can continue their passions for music::: dance::: theater::: and other performing arts.  From scholarships::: new clubs and classes::: private music lessons::: community partnerships::: and exciting new venues being built on campus::: performing arts for RIT students is literally becoming a show stopper. https://bddy.me/3mUrvfV  RIT.EDU Setting the Stage for the Performing Academic | RIT
column3: This news is so welcome. It is exciting to see RIT expand on its amazing::: high quality academics in the arts.  It speaks to my formative experiences at RIT in the 1980s. I got my bachelors in electrical engineering and got involved in the theater and dance programs at NTID. I joined the RIT Gospel Ensemble too. I was thrilled by the quality of opportunities and productions that I got involved in. I worked costumes and sets::: choreographed dances::: and danced and sang in many productions. Through my NTID connections::: I was offered an internship at the Geva Theater at the end of my time at RIT though I couldn‚Äôt accept due to my commitments to the US AIr Force. I often wonder ‚Äúwhat if‚Äù.  Rochester is a mighty town for the arts and RIT has been a major contributor for decades. Teaching students the industry and getting them connected to launch their career is what RIT does exceptionally. RIT also taught me the great things that happen when we make simple but transformationa l accommodations to broaden access to the arts. Engineering gave me technical chops to succeed in my career in advanced computation but the arts gave me the agency (and the stage) to try out the ideas that became my most significant contributions.  Bravissimo! Encore! Encore! More! More!
column4: This is cool. Seriously wasn't a big thing when I was there from 2016-2021.  But is RIT ever going to develop a broadcast program? We have the ability with the Film/Animation Dept. + Journalism Dept. We have SportsZone as a sports outlet to develop PxP::: On-Air Reporters::: Anchors and give students reps in sports. We could develop a digital news site through the School of Comm and students can work at the Reporter to get reps. We have WITR as a radio outlet::: MAGIC studios as a home base for live news and entertainment shows::: you can start with just pre-recorded digital media and expand to live tv. Janet Lomax (legend in local news) is on campus and you have other professors that have worked in the industry or close enough where you might be able to offer a minor or a few classes. Link up with local news::: radio and print business for internships and boom.  I know easier said then done but that'd be cool to see one day.

column16: Not to take anything away from her achievement::: because it is a ton of work to become an Eagle Scout::: but it‚Äôs sickening the exceptions that are being made for women. It‚Äôs easy as an adult to see the advantage and importance of achieving Eagle Scout. I would guess that many boys would like the opportunity at age 17::: 18:::19 to begin this endeavor.  Both of my sons have achieved Eagle Scout. It was a long road and something they had to stick with over many years. Additionally::: it wasn‚Äôt the popular thing in school so they had to rise above that challenge also. I just think giving these girls an extension because of a rule change in 2019 is unfair to both the boys that can‚Äôt do the same and to the girls who really didn‚Äôt experience what it was like to stick with a plan for years while juggling everything else in a student‚Äôs life. Just my opinion of course::: but as I stated::: many boys might like to have this same extension. column10: Administration should get strong . Enough is enough . I too wish we did not need a mandate. Unfortunately::: the best way out of this pandemic is vaccination. Every vaccination has very tiny risk . They all have . Vaccinations have probably saved more lives across the last 75 years than any other medical accomplishment. Are they extending deadline for students ? Doubt it . Have one standard. I was raised to respect one another and i do . Unfortunately when a sizeable proportion of any group is unvaxxed it effects the health of others . In a pandemic the personal heslth choices cannot be entirely personal because every individual can create problems for others . In my work as a healthcare worker ive seen too many elderly die following exposure to unvaccinated family members who were younger and were irresponsible. Senseless really . Nothing about vaccination should ever have gotten wrapped in a political blanket . Science helping as best as possible . Never perfect . The success of covid vaccination is unprecedented. How quickly people forget dead bodies in refrigerated trucks outside major metropolitan hospitals during the surges we have had . Maybe enough have gotten vaccinated and enough have gotten sick and recovered with natural immunity to prevent another surge . Certainly hope that is true . That is what may be the natural course of this pandemic undisturbed by the help from Medicine or vaccine or the hard work of caring for those who happen to require help when they get sick . I would think most RIT grads would be smart enough to avoid political icing on this cake ...

column3: Is There a Cure for Racism and other forms of prejudice? ‚ÄúPrejudice is like a virus. It harms its victims::: and people can be unaware that they are infected.‚Äù  How can we avoid flawed ways of thinking that can lead to prejudice? What can we do to remove prejudice from within us?  ‚ÄúGet to know others personally: Learn not to stereotype::: preferably strive to understand another person‚Äôs struggles and how their experiences have shaped their personality. Develop a positive attitude toward them::: show empathy::: and start valuing them more::: grow as close as possible to them; many prejudices will evaporate into thin air by that moment.‚Äù  Instead of drawing negative conclusions about a person who is from a particular group of people::: ask yourself: Am I focusing too much on how different others are from me? Do I view myself as superior? If so::: you could conclude that such differences are flaws or defects on the other hand humility allows you to recognize that in some areas of life others are superior.  ‚ÄúI once felt prejudice toward immigrants: I did not characterize my feelings as prejudice::: because this was how the majority of people viewed immigrants.‚Äù  https:// www.jw.org/ finder?srcid=jwl share&wtlocale= E&prefer=lang&p ub=g20&issue=20 2011

column1: The week started with Fall Break on Monday and Tuesday::: which left the campus quiet. But the rest of the week was very full of activities and events leading up to Brick City Weekend.  After two years away from the runway::: metals and jewelry design students and alumni in both RIT's College of Art and Design and the School for American Crafts triumphantly returned to Rochester Fashion Week with a stunning demonstration of technology::: art::: and design.  RIT welcomed Alumni Alex Kipman::: '01 (software engineering) back to campus. A technical fellow at Microsoft and inventor of the Kinect and HoloLens products::: Kipman met and spoke with students before his presentation as part of the 20th anniversary celebrations of the Golisano College of Computing and Information Sciences.  Students participated in the annual ‚ÄòJump for Jude‚Äô fundraiser sponsored by TKE fraternity::: enjoyed the unseasonably warm weather::: and continued their studies and research projects::: such as Kritina Chomiak::: and Environmental Science Grad student working at RIT's Tait Preserve on measuring the light availability in the water in order to understand how the characteristics of the lake influence biofilm formation and degradation of plastic debris.  The 67th Rochester Finger Lakes Exhibition will wrap up on Sunday::: October 17. This year RIT had 28 pieces by either students::: faculty::: staff or alumni.

Students at RIT hoping to enter the healthcare IT workforce now have a jumpstart::: as we join up with the New York state chapter of the Healthcare Information and Management Systems Society (HIMSS).  HIMSS is an academic organizational partner that allows students to take part in seminars and virtual events::: as well as a way for students to connect with industry partners looking to fill internships::: co-ops::: and full-time positions.  https://bddy.me/3aJ3B0d  RIT.EDU RIT joins with New York state chapter of HIMSS to help students start careers in healthcare IT management

column3: My son had covid in the past couple weeks- hopefully he doesn't get the Norovirus- one thing we did notice::: only one class had an online option. He missed an entire week of classes. Since there are so many health concerns::: maybe this should be addressed? Kids may be more apt to stay in their room if they don't feel like missing a class with cause them to flunk. Too much pressure for kids that are high achievers and highly stressed people.
column4: Please revise your policies so students who are sick can miss class without consequence if they contact the teacher to let them know they're missing class because they might be contagious and they make up the work. My son isn't sick but got a 0 on an assignment when the professor accidentally deleted the topics that they needed to do the assignment and then told them to email her by a certain time BEFORE the assignment was even due or they were out of luck. My son was busy grading other students' work::: doing a job for the benefit of the university. Not everyone checks their email 10 times a day. These punitive types of grading policies where you miss a class or two because you're sick have to stop. There's enough stress during covid and we need to give all people - especially students who are already under pressure and being pulled in various directions - a bit of grace. Still no update on whether the student who was found unresponsive died due to suicide? I hope not due to the pressures at college. So what if a student they missed a class or two::: especially if because they were trying to be responsible and not spread a contagious illness? Should they really be penalized for that?! The mental health and wellness of students always comes first. RIT definitely needs a college-wide policy on this because otherwise students are at the mercy of individual teachers with a bunch of varying policies. It's like when you have a disability and need accommodations. If you're sick::: you have a temporary condition that needs to be taken into consideration. You cannot be treated the same as a student who just couldn't be bothered to go to class.

column1: On September 11::: 2001::: RIT alum Rick Kettell ‚Äô84 (logistics and transportation management) tracked Flight 93::: one of four flights hijacked by terrorists::: from his position as an air traffic manager at the Cleveland Air Route Traffic Control Center.  In his moving and informative essay::: Kettell shares memories from that day::: from how he kept top military leaders and intelligence agencies informed::: tracked Flight 93's crash into a field in Shanksville::: PA::: and helped to safely land 4:::500 aircraft after all air traffic was shut down across the United States.  "For the next 25 minutes::: I shared the hijacker‚Äôs commands and Flight 93‚Äôs navigational status with constant updates on that teleconference::: as we scrambled to find a way to intervene:::" Kettel writes. "My communication updates were necessary because the hijackers had turned off the transponder of the aircraft::: and I was the only person who had the ability to follow the intermittent radar target."  https://bddy.me/3hpiCrF  RIT.EDU Alumnus who tracked Flight 93 as air traffic manager shares his 9/11 memories
column3: This was a really interesting article. His experience was so different from the rest of us that day.
column4: I remember being on campus during the morning of September 11. As we all watched with shock as the buildings fell::: and our friends in schools all over the country took off that day to mourn the people that have been killed::: and some schools close down for the rest of the week RIT did absolutely nothing.  It is a fitting tribute to the school that could not send out an email for 12 hours::: could not declare a day off from classes::: could not open itself up to the misery that we were feeling.

column5: The vaccine DOES WORK in multiple ways! So tired of hearing that going back to masks means the vaccine doesn‚Äôt work! One is not a cause or result of the other. They are BOTH protective actions. The vaccine provides protection from the virus::: including better than 50% from the delta variant. What wearing a mask does is add to your protection and helps make sure that if you are asymptomatic that you limit your spread of the virus. If preventing members of your own campus community from getting sick isn‚Äôt reason enough to get vaccinated AND wear a mask::: then think about the healthcare system and most importantly the workers. You taking these steps means the system will not be maxed out and the workers stressed to the point of mental and physical exhaustion or worse. 99.9% of those vaccinated who get sick will NOT need hospitalization ::: to be placed in ICU::: or die from the virus. And wearing a mask::: vaccinated or unvaccinated stops the spread to anyone - including those who could end up hospitalized::: in ICU::: or dying - some with legitimate reasons to be exempt from the vaccine. Please thank your university for asking of all its members the MOST responsible set of actions in the spirit of caring for those on campus and in the community that hosts you! Go Tigers!

column1: Lynn Fuller::: the founder of the Microelectronic engineering program::: is retiring from Kate Gleason College of Engineering. Fuller established the first microelectronic engineering program in the country in 1982 at RIT::: and today many program graduates lead efforts at the top microchip firms and advise President Joe Biden in support of Biden's recent call for more resources to bolster the computer chip industry to meet consumer and commercial demands.  Teacher and mentor define Fuller best. When he formally retires in June::: the alumnus of the engineering college will have earned multiple awards and recognitions over a notable career‚Äîas RIT‚Äôs first NCAA All-American::: a two-time Eisenhart honoree for excellence in teaching::: an influential program administrator::: IEEE Fellow::: patent-holder::: and inductee into RIT‚Äôs Sports Hall of Fame and the university‚Äôs Innovation Hall of Fame. https://bddy.me/3uapRHH  RIT.EDU Microelectronic engineering program founder retires from Kate Gleason College of Engineering

Rochester Institute of Technology has named Albany State (Ga.) Associate Athletics Director Jacqueline Nicholson its next Executive Director of Intercollegiate Athletics.  Set to become only the fifth athletic director in program history::: Nicholson succeeds the nation's longest-tenured AD::: Lou Spiotti Jr.::: who recently announced his retirement following 47 years of service at RIT::: including the last 41 running the athletic department.  "We are excited to welcome Jackie to the RIT Tiger family. The university is moving forward on many major initiatives and athletics is a key part of our agenda:::" said RIT President David Munson. "RIT Athletics::: with all of its tradition and history::: has a very bright future with Jackie at the helm."  RITATHLETICS.COM Jacqueline Nicholson named Executive Director of Intercollegiate Athletics - Rochester Institute of Technology Athletics  RIT Athletics May 18::: 2021 at 8:00 AM ¬∑  Jacqueline Nicholson named Executive Director of Intercollegiate Athletics

column27: Illegal.  ICAN (Informed Consent Action Network) lawyers are writing letters to the universities and colleges mandating the EUA's::: to remind them that it is illegal to mandate them.  Here is some of that info::: copied from an email I got from them today:  "Recently::: numerous colleges and universities around the country have announced mandates for students::: and some for faculty::: requiring receipt of a COVID-19 vaccine as a condition of attendance or employment. ICAN has been receiving a steady stream of complaints from students at these universities. ICAN has asked its attorneys to send letters to these universities making clear that these mandates violate federal law::: international laws::: civil and individual rights::: and public policy. At the end of March::: Rutgers University announced that it would require COVID-19 vaccines for students enrolled in its Fall 2021 semester. Since then::: ICAN has been contacted by students and faculty members from dozens of schools whose universities have followed suit with their own mandates. ICAN‚Äôs mission states that ‚Äúyou are the authority over your health choices and those of your children‚Äù ‚Äì not a university president or chancellor. Therefore::: ICAN::: through its attorneys::: has contacted dozens of universities that have taken your health choices and your children‚Äôs health choices into their own hands. The letters to schools including Cornell::: Duke University::: Fordham::: Northeastern::: Notre Dame::: NYU::: Pace University::: Rider University::: University of Pennsylvania::: Sarah Lawrence College::: St. John‚Äôs::: Trinity College::: University of Colorado::: University of Maryland::: University of Massachusetts::: Wake Forest University::: Yale::: and many more listed below:::* make clear that it is a violation of federal law to mandate receipt of a product that is only available pursuant to an emergency use authorization (EUA). The universities therefore cannot lawfully require students to receive a COVID-19 vaccine that is being distributed under an EUA.  By implementing a vaccine mandate::: the universities are deliberately taking away each student‚Äôs statutorily guaranteed right to decide whether to accept or refuse administration of the COVID-19 vaccines. These universities are doing so openly::: without any regard for the personal and autonomous right of each student to choose whether they want to receive an unapproved and unlicensed medical product. They are effectively forcing each student to choose between facing expulsion from the school or receiving an experimental medical treatment to which they do not consent.  ICAN reminded the schools that the right to informed medical consent is considered a fundamental::: overriding principle of medical ethics and international law::: first laid down by United States government jurists in the Nuremberg Code which states: ‚ÄúThe voluntary consent of the human subject is absolutely essential. This means that the person‚Ä¶[is] able to exercise free power of choice::: without the intervention of any element of‚Ä¶coercion.‚Äù Public policy further demands that uncoerced consent is required. Congress made this clear in its laws by assuring that individuals can make their own medical decisions when it comes to EUA products::: even during times of emergency. This clear policy choice made at the highest levels of government to protect the individual‚Äôs right to choose is further supported by the fact that whether COVID-19 vaccines are actually safe and effective is not yet known::: including because the Phase III clinical trials have not yet even concluded! ICAN pointed out another concerning issue: these schools are failing to take into consideration that a significant portion of their student population is likely to have had SARS-CoV-2 and fully recovered. Putting aside the immunity conferred by having been previously infected::: there have been concerns raised by medical professionals that vaccinating those recently infected can lead to serious injury or death by causing antigen specific tissue inflammation in any tissues harboring viral antigens. ICAN explained that the schools should consider whether they might be liable for any damages::: poor health outcomes::: and loss of life due to mandatory COVID-19 vaccination policies forced upon its students. While manufacturers and vaccine administrators are protected by the PREP Act::: mandating universities are not. Of course::: people also have the right to decline attendance and to take themselves and their tuition to other colleges that support medical autonomy ‚Äì this is one potential way to allow your voice to be heard. In the meantime::: ICAN will continue sending letters to universities that take your medical choices into their hands."

A team of nearly 50 researchers led by scientists at Rochester Institute of Technology and University of Texas at Austin will attempt to do so through the COSMOS-Webb program::: the largest General Observer program selected for JWST‚Äôs first year.  ‚ÄúThe sheer scope of our program is so exciting:::‚Äù said principal investigator Jeyhan Kartaltepe::: an assistant professor in RIT‚Äôs School of Physics and Astronomy. ‚ÄúThe first year of Webb observations will result in a lot of new discoveries that people will want explore more in-depth in future cycles. https://bddy.me/2QNkdh0  RIT.EDU James Webb Space Telescope program aims to map the earliest structures of the universe

column3: There are groups of Vaccine Hunters in most states - with Facebook pages. These volunteers have been there and done it and many have posted tips and tricks that can help you score a vaccine appointment without a lot of aggravation. I used what I learned from my state‚Äôs Vaccine Hunters to get my appointment confirmed within minutes after they were made available. In my state::: there are more ‚Äúwalk-up‚Äù shots available - no appointment required. Good luck with the end of the semester - and getting your shot(s)!
column4: I live in Brazil::: where vaccination is so behind... Some cities don't even have enough to give people the second dose. Hospitals show reduced numbers of hospitalized older people thanks to the vaccination. Younger people are getting sicker now and most people don't have easy or cheap access to tests::: which helps the virus circulate::: increasing the risk of new variants. My son is a student at RIT and he is getting the second dose next week. I wish I could get mine::: but there is no expectation for people under 60 to get vaccinated if there are no comorbities. RIT is a place for science and I hope all students understand the importance of the vaccine at this point.

column1: A team of RIT cybersecurity students is heading to nationals this weekend::: to face-off against nine of the best cybersecurity colleges in the country. The students are competing in the National Collegiate Cyber Defense Competition (NCCDC)::: which is held virtually this year. RIT won the Northeast regional competition in March to get an automatic bid to nationals.  In the competition::: which runs from April 23-25::: student teams work to prevent a team of industry professionals from breaking into computer networks to exploit information.  RIT‚Äôs cyber defense team is a perennial contender at the regional and national competitions. The Tigers won their region last year::: making it to the nationals. The team placed third at nationals in 2019 and won the whole competition back in 2013.  The RIT student team is made up of computing security majors Phillip Babey::: a third year (Newark Valley::: NY)::: Omar Aljaloud::: a third-year (Saudi Arabia)::: Jack Audino::: a first-year (Mendham::: NJ)::: Ayane Naito::: a second-year (Brooklyn::: NY)::: Craig Gebo::: a third-year (Rochester::: NY)::: Robert Gray::: a third-year (Canandaigua::: NY)::: Daniel Szafran::: a fourth-year (Colrain::: MA) Jacob Cedar::: a second-year (Brooklyn::: NY)::: Jason Howe::: a second-year (Boston::: MA)::: Kayla Hodgson::: a second-year (Woodbridge::: VA)::: Enzo DeStephano::: a third-year (Webster::: NY)::: and Brayden Werner::: a second-year (Colombia::: MD).

column27: In search of black holes and dark matter astrophysicists are relying on indirect observations. It would seem that the measurement of the event horizon of a black hole directly would be a direct evidence. However::: by the nature of a horizon::: any real measurement of the event horizon will be indirect. The Event Horizon Telescope will get picture of the silhouette of the Sgr A* which is due to optical effects of spacetime outside of the event horizon. The result will be determined by the simple quality of the resulting image that does not depend on the properties of the spacetime within the image. So::: it will be also indirect and an existence of BH is a hypothesis. https:// www.academia.edu /12468184/ Are_there_Black_ Holes_and_Dark_ Matter_in_the_M ilky_Way

column1: Dr. Munson‚Äôs Performing Arts Challenge was a great success this past Friday. Held virtually this year due to the pandemic::: RIT's President David C. Munson Jr.::: and his wife Nancy Munson welcomed judges and remote audiences to the Performing Arts festival. In the auditorium::: the Munsons were joined by the event‚Äôs judges who sat socially distanced from one another to view the performances of the finalists. Each performance was judged on artistry::: technique::: audience engagement::: and stage presence.  The Brick City Singers took first place and the $1:::000 top prize.  Second place::: and $500::: was awarded to Paige Arieno::: a second-year environmental science major from Rochester who danced to ‚ÄúBillie:::‚Äù with choreography by Kristie Schillaci of The Floor Dance Company. The piece was filmed outside on the RIT campus and in the tunnels under Sol Heumann Hall.  And Taylor Greider::: a first-year applied mathematics major from Greece::: N.Y.::: who performed a contemporary dance piece::: ‚ÄúIn Love:::‚Äù with original choreography::: won Third place and $250.  Congratulations to all the finalists for their amazing artistry and dedication to the performing arts. The finalists were:  "Sir Duke" Performed by Riley Kranick  "Imagine" Performed by Jarell Green  "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" Performed by Ian Freezman  "Home" Performed by Shiann Cook  "Like You" Performed by Desire Chiruza  "Borodin's String Quartet No. 2 Mvt. 3" Performed by Red Brick String Quartet  "Summertime Sadness" Performed by Lily Domes  "The Ballad of Lucy Gray Baird" Performed by Meghan Wengert  "In Love" Performed by Taylor Greider  "Eventually" Performed by RIT Brick City Singers  "Billie" Performed by Paige Arieno

A message from President Munson concerning our RIT family at RIT Croatia:  Dear RIT Community::: We have been keeping apprised of the situation in Croatia after two earthquakes hit the region earlier this week. The first::: on Monday::: registered a magnitude of 5.3::: which was followed by a magnitude 6.4 quake on Tuesday. The epicenters were approximately 30 miles from our campus in the capital of Zagreb. RIT Croatia President and Dean Don Hudspeth reports that all of the campus community is safe and there was no damage to our Zagreb facility. However::: there was heavy damage in outlying towns and villages::: and several reported deaths. And aside from all the challenges associated with the COVID-19 pandemic::: it has been a difficult year as Zagreb was also struck by a magnitude 5.5 earthquake on March 22nd::: which resulted in extensive damage to the city. Know that we are here to support our RIT Croatia family in every way. We are a global family. On this last day of 2020::: let‚Äôs cherish and be grateful for all that we have. Together we will persevere and bring goodness to the world. Onward and upward in 2021!  David Munson RIT President

column3: I've recently been trying to find a way to express to the simple-minded the possible paths of students through math classes in our middle/high schools::: and am therefore quite sympathetic right now to the goal of expressing complex information in simple form. However::: is the yellow line above correct? Why would "apparent infected in the first 100 days" drop like that? Shouldn't it - at best - achieve a slope of zero (as does the green line)? As it is::: it implies that the "apparent infections" found in the first 100 days all turned out to be false positives::: which seems unlikely.  Perhaps the label is wrong::: and it should be "...last 100 days" instead of "...first 100 days"? EDIT: No::: even that doesn't work given the horizontal scale. The slope would only go negative in that case after day 100.

Matthew Wright::: of our Global Cybersecurity Institute::: is among several researchers receiving funding from the Knight Foundation to develop tools that help journalists combat misinformation.  https://bddy.me/2VhrdS2  KNIGHTFOUNDATION.ORG Knight Foundation announces nearly $3 million for projects to help journalists combat misinformation
column3: It's gratifying to see such efforts being undertaken to fight misinformation (fake news). We live in the world where anyone can make their own version of news and spread it with lightning speed. News are manufactured to anybody's liking. That's not right and is even dangerous. One suggestion would be to create self-regulatory organizations (federal and state) formed by largest industry players and where professional journalists would be required to become members::: pass exams::: and take continuing education (including ethics) to maintain their licenses. Articles made by such registered journalists/ organizations would carry their license number and name of issuing organization for public to see. Anyone else who writes news but is not a registered journalist would not have such registration and readers would be able to tell them from professional::: licensed journalists. important thing here is to let public know what category the news belongs to and let them make informed decision of trusting that news or seeing it as entertainment::: someone's opinion::: scientific facts::: editorial::: etc. similar rules should be developed for networks that spread information.

column34: I'm a nurse who has been taking care of sick people::: including COVID19. Since it is already a requirement that students wear masks::: it should not be an issue if not every student is vaccinated or not! You are telling every student that they must have material injected into their body! That is just WRONG!!!! RIT is an extremely diverse school and I'm sure there a students with beliefs against this vaccination. I am all for the flu vaccine::: I get every year::: my children have received it since birth::: my husband is a PT in a nursing home and he gets it too but that is OUR CHOICE!!!!! Seriously RIT???? This is ridiculous and wrong!!!!

column55: There is no justification for a flu mandate. From the WHO website: The various hygiene and physical distancing measures implemented by Member States to reduce SARS-CoV-2 virus transmission have likely played a role in reducing influenza virus transmission. Globally::: influenza activity was reported at lower levels than expected for this time of the year. In the temperate zones of the southern hemisphere::: the influenza season has not started. Despite continued or even increased testing for influenza in some countries in the southern hemisphere::: very few influenza detections were reported. In the temperate zone of the northern hemisphere::: influenza activity remained below inter-seasonal levels. In the Caribbean and Central American countries::: no influenza detections were reported. Severe acute respiratory infection (SARI) activity::: likely due to COVID-19::: appeared to decrease in some reporting countries. In tropical South America::: tropical Africa and Southern Asia there were sporadic or no influenza detections across reporting countries. In South East Asia::: influenza A(H3N2) virus detections were reported in Cambodia. Worldwide::: of the very low numbers of detections reported::: seasonal influenza A viruses accounted for the majority of detections.

column14: I hope Spring has a break::: some breaks...the students and the faculty are already burned out with no break in sight til Thanksgiving this semester...I agree that breaks that allow people to travel to hot spots and back again is not a good idea::: but maybe a few "study days" sprinkled in for Spring semester if we are "concerned" about Spring break...14-15 weeks straight gets exhausting::: though I anticipated this and have a light week or two sprinkled into this semester and will do the same for the Spring if there are no real breaks. Mental health and well-being are really important.  There are both students and faculty that need to be remote due to a) high risk or b) international students who couldn't get back. If class schedules can be set up so there is flexibility for those who must go remote and flexibility for those who want to be live::: that would be best. This semester::: for example::: 2 sections of a course were taught by people who did it live so I know students who couldn't take the course the semester they should have due to having to be remote::: but this semester coming up::: the course's 2 sections have a live section and a remote section::: so students can choose their modality...the more this is considered when making up the schedule::: the better for everyone I think...for the Fall semester::: there were just too many moving parts::: but now for the Spring::: a lot of things are already in place.

column1: Today‚Äôs COVID-19 alert level remains Green::: representing a low risk with a continued need for vigilance. A level of ‚Äúgreen‚Äù means the prevalence of COVID-19 in the area is low::: however there remains the risk of outbreaks.  Wasterwater surveillance has been one of the many steps we are taking to protect the campus community. Recent wastewater surveillance led us to test all residents Friday in Nathaniel Rochester Hall. The good news is that results came back late last night and showed only one new positive case in the entire residence hall. The identified person is currently off-campus. We are working with health officials to isolate the person and quarantine those the person came in close contact with.  Surveillance testing has also indicated the need to test students and staff in three additional dorms::: Kate Gleason Hall::: Residence Hall B and Eugene Colby Hall (A::: B::: C::: D::: E::: F). That testing is being carried out this morning. Testing activities will continue throughout the semester as we detect signals of spread. We realize this can be inconvenient::: but we also know it is one way to work to prevent the spread of COVID. It remains important for all members of the RIT community to wear a mask when in the vicinity of others and watch your spacing with others.  We continue to update the community via our dashboard and our alert level. You can learn more at https://bddy.me/35cNV3U  RIT.EDU RIT COVID-19 Dashboard | RIT Ready | RIT

column16: A university is supposed to be an area for the free and open exchange of ideas. Reporting people for a ‚ÄúBias-related incident‚Äù is the antithesis of that resulting in intimidation and limiting free speech. Physical violence to make a point is wrong::: differing opinions are not. Is rooting for the Buffalo Bills Football team a bias-related incident? In reality pretty much everything we do is bias related whenever we have an opinion. Who are the bias related judges who will determine our punishment for sharing our opinions if they upset someone else? This sounds an awful lot like Hitler‚Äôs brown shirts.  Here is an idea::: instead of spending thousands of dollars on diversity and inclusion programs::: we explain to students that throughout life they will encounter people who disagree with them sometimes in very nasty (but non-violent) ways. This is part of life and more often than not you can‚Äôt change them. You only change the way you respond to the them (in a civil and mature way) and how you manage your own metal health. That is what I thought a University was supposed to teach::: not develop ‚Äúsafe spaces‚Äù and policing to shield people from the realities of life.  By this post I am not endorsing abusive words::: insensitive behavior or sexual or racial harassment of anyone or any group by anyone::: only pointing out the realities of life. RIT should be equipping students deal with them.
column17: A lot of you alumni in the comments are so shameful of what RIT is. Times have changed. Black lives matter. Black students on campus need support::: as we all do on campus and everywhere else in the world. This is one step towards being able to hold people accountable for their actions::: and if it doesn't work::: its another measure RIT is trying to take towards equality on campus. This is the real world we live in- racism is a problem everywhere::: and the fact that some of you can't see that shows what kind of person you are. Racism shouldn't be a reality but it is. That's the real world we live in::: and until some of you guys care and realize that::: we'll never get the sweeping change we need. "Tattling" is not a bad thing- it keeps people safe and feel more comfortable on this campus. I'm assuming you all are loving the white faculty anti-racism thing as well? White families and students thrive here. Should be the same for all races. Go put your alumni money elsewhere::: I'm sure RIT won't need it with the money RIT makes from everyone else.
column18: Tom Van Epps

column20: I came across this on another page::: thought it appropriate here. As long as you define a racist as an individual who intentionally is mean::: based on race::: you‚Äôre going to feel defensive.  When I say you‚Äôve been shaped by a racist system‚Äîthat it is inevitable that you have racist biases and patterns and investments‚Äîyou ‚Äôre going to feel offended by that. You will hear it as a comment on your moral character. You‚Äôre going to feel offended by that if you don‚Äôt change how you‚Äôre interpreting what I just said.  And I would actually agree with anyone who felt offended when I say::: ‚ÄúIt is inevitable that you are racist:::‚Äù if their definition of a racist is someone who means harm.  When we understand racism as a system that we have been raised in and that its impact is inevitable::: it‚Äôs really not a question of good or bad. It‚Äôs just::: ‚ÄúI have it. I have been socialized into it.‚Äù  And so::: ‚ÄúWhat am I going to do about it?‚Äù is really the question. And that‚Äôs where::: I think::: maybe some guilt could come in::: when you know that and you‚Äôre still not going to do anything about it.  I don‚Äôt struggle with guilt because::: to the best of my ability::: I am trying to challenge my socialization. So::: let me be really clear: As a result of being raised as a white person in this society::: I have a racist worldview. I have racist biases. I have developed racist patterns as a result::: and I have investments in the system of racism.  It‚Äôs incredibly comfortable. It‚Äôs certainly helped me with the barriers that I do face. And I also have investments in not seeing anything I just said‚Äîbecause of what it would suggest to me about my identity as a good person::: if I‚Äôm coming from the dominant definition::: and what it would actually require of me in action. I don‚Äôt feel guilty about that::: but I do feel responsible for what I do with that socialization.  Change how you understand what it means to be racist::: and then act on that understanding. Because if you change your understanding::: but you don‚Äôt do anything different::: then you‚Äôre colluding.  https:// www.tolerance.or g/‚Ä¶/ whats-my-complic ity-talking-whi ‚Ä¶

Students and families have had to change hotel reservations and plane flights multiple times to accommodate this. Unlike it's university neighbors::: RIT is not working with a nearby hotel to develop packages to subsidize the cost. Or created an option for financially disenfranchised students to participating in a supervised quarantine on campus. With this plan::: RIT has turned their backs on their students with financial barriers. Most students will not be able to afford to follow these steps. RIT has also dropped the ball on communication. Now::: one of those images is NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Astronomy Picture of the Day. Take a look!  Astronomy Picture of the Day (APOD) added a new photo to the album: APOD 2020 June. June 29::: 2020 at 8:11 PM ¬∑  APOD: Bright Planetary Nebula NGC 7027 from Hubble (2020 Jun 30) Image Credit: NASA::: ESA::: Joel Kastner (RIT) et al.; Processing: Alyssa Pagan (STScI) https://apod.nasa.gov/apod/ap200630.html  Explanation: What created this unusual planetary nebula? NGC 7027 is one of the smallest::: brightest::: and most unusually shaped planetary nebulas known. Given its expansion rate::: NGC 7027 first started expanding::: as visible from Earth::: about 600 years ago. For much of its history::: the planetary nebula has been expelling shells::: as seen in blue in the featured image. In modern times::: though::: for reasons unknown::: it began ejecting gas and dust (seen in red) in specific directions that created a new pattern that seems to have four corners. These shells and patterns have been mapped in impressive detail by recent images from the Wide Field Camera 3 onboard the Hubble Space Telescope. What lies at the nebula's center is unknown::: with one hypothesis holding it to be a close binary star system where one star sheds gas onto an erratic disk orbiting the other star. NGC 7027::: about 3:::000 light years away::: was first discovered in 1878 and can be seen with a standard backyard telescope toward the constellation of the Swan (Cygnus).  https://www.nasa.gov/ https://www.esa.int/ https://www.rit.edu/directory/jhkpci-joel-kastner https://www.rit.edu/ https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2020AAS...23530703K/abstract https://www.stsci.edu/  Starship Asterisk* ‚Ä¢ APOD Discussion Page http://asterisk.apod.com/discuss_apod.php?date=200630  #APOD

column1: Professor Joel Kastner and Ph.D. students Jesse Bublitz and Paula Moraga used the Hubble Space Telescope to capture some incredible images of planetary nebulae that tell us a lot about Sun-like stars at the end of their lives.  Hubble Space Telescope June 18::: 2020 at 9:15 AM ¬∑  New multi-wavelength images of nebulas from the Hubble Space Telescope show rapid changes in material blasting off stars at their centers. In the case of NGC 6302::: better known as the Butterfly Nebula::: two recently ejected S-shaped streams may be the result of two stars interacting at its core. The same is true for NGC 7027: A new cloverleaf pattern may also point to the interactions of two central stars. Both nebulas are splitting themselves apart on extremely short timescales::: allowing researchers to measure changes in their structures over only a few decades. Keep reading: http://ow.ly/wyXn50A9thP

column15: I‚Äôm curious to try and understand the relationship between the parent/student listening sessions held this week and this announcement.  We met in groups on Thursday night and were told that there was no information available (these sessions were recorded)::: and that there likely wouldn‚Äôt be until after the Governor made recommendations .  And yet::: about seventeen hours later::: a plan was widely distributed.  Obviously::: the plan existed prior to these meetings::: and an opportunity to actually discuss specifics was there::: rather than what actually happened - a good faith contribution on the part of those who chose to attend::: thinking that opinions::: thoughts::: and concerns would perhaps be taken into consideration before making a final plan.  I will not judge whether this was the intent or not::: but it gives the appearance that these meetings were held in an attempt to allow stakesholders to believe that they had some voice in the decision-making process::: while the plan existed well before the meetings took place.

column1: The killing of George Floyd and protests around the world against systemic injustice and inequality have prompted the RIT community to more closely examine its role in working to end racism. We‚Äôre launching a conversation to reinforce that Black Lives Matter. University leadership has pledged that the conversation::: no matter how uncomfortable::: must continue. Share your comments and ideas with us here.  YOUTUBE.COM An RIT Conversation on Racism
column3: Where do you people live that racism is a problem? I don't see it::: but::: then again::: I'm not looking for it::: or to virtue signal when the media tells me to
column4: Alumni from the 90s. I've tried having this conversation many times over during my days of walking the 1/4 mile. Wasn't much different back then to now. At least now white kids are joining the protest. Real issues won't be addressed until "everyday racism" is solved. In my opinion that type of racism is far worse than Floyd's death. But it won't be addressed any time soon because white liberals are guilty of it. If it were trump supporters::: they'd be on it immediately. That woman who called the cops on that black guy couldn't tell the difference between a criminal and a 57 year old :::bird watching::: Marvel comics writer::: gay pioneer. She was a liberal Democrat in the a blue liberal city::: nyc. Most of the white women doing that are white liberal women doing that. Watch where they're from next time::: San fran::: NYC::: ivy league universities. Conservative women don't even have to go there::: they don't pretend or create facades. They have their hoods and rope handy. Many black people would prefer the enemy in plain sight.
column5: We're never going to solve racism with solutions that are inherently segregated or discriminatory. We say Black Lives Matter today because they have not mattered in the past::: however that phrase is problematic because the semantics seem to elevate the value of black lives above all others.  We need solutions that bring people together and treat them as equals regardless of the color of their skin. Too many of the solutions these days revolve around treating people differently based on the color of their skin. This approach will only exacerbate our differences and create resentment.  Solving racism is about moving forward together toward a better future::: not about exacting revenge for the injustices of the past.
column6: This will all be forgotten. Just a turbulent time. Yes I said it. Guilty ? Not ! America 1st and that‚Äôs every single one of us.
column7: Omar Sheikh
column8: Thank you for moving from "the tragic death" to acknowledge that he was killed. We need to be bold and call things what they are ‚úäüèº‚úäüèª‚úäüèΩ
column9: Red::: brown::: yellow and white lives matter as well. Do not exclude one particular color. Solve problems for all groups.
column10: Not all racism is overt. Most of it is covert and actually unrecognized by the people doing it. It's in hiring practices::: evaluation and promotion practices. It's in advertising and entertainment. It's in slogans::: mottos::: fight songs::: and team names. It's in words used and not used. It's in the news and perceptions formed by viewing that news. Racism isn't just a physical knee to the neck or slur on the street.
column11: Dialogue always welcome.
column12: The N word was written at my sons dorm. I don‚Äôt believe much or if anything was done to address or find the person who did it. No student should be subjected to hatred. This is not what we send our kids to school for. No one is better than anyone else.
column13: Thank you for leading the way::: RIT! Proud alumnus::: twice over. The conversation must absolutely continue!
column14: The best conversations are the ones that make everyone uncomfortable. Unless people say how they really feel/think::: nothing will change.

column1: Thank you to everyone who reached out to remind us how much #Blacktigersmatter. Tonight during the Calls for Justice vigil::: President Munson announced that RIT is finding a home to permanently display the Black Lives Matter flag in the student union. It will represent our commitment to ending systemic racism and injustice::: not only at RIT::: but in the world in which we live.  We will also be adding the Haudenosaunee flag to honor the six nations that form the Haudenosaunee confederacy and it is their land upon which our university resides::: and the International Deaf Culture flag in support of the Deaf community. All three will hang alongside the rainbow Pride flag::: which is already hanging in the union.  We know that this represents a single step and we all have a lot more to do. We pledge to do that work together. Watch for an announcement of a townhall for the RIT community in the coming days. Black lives matter.

column1: Rochester Institute of Technology added 24 new photos ‚Äî with Taylor Carpenter and 2 others. May 8::: 2020 at 10:59 AM ¬∑ More options  The pandemic may have scrapped a traditional commencement ceremony this year::: but it hasn't stopped our graduates and families from celebrating. Since campus won't be full of families celebrating today::: photographer Elizabeth Lamark brought her camera to some area grads.

We know this wasn't how things were supposed to be. We wish you were all lining up to process into the field house right now. We wish the slope outside was about to be full of families ready to take your picture.  But though we had to cancel commencement::: this day still stands as a marker of your amazing achievements. We are incredibly proud of your hard work::: your accomplishments and your perseverance. We're proud that even in the middle of all of this::: more of you are graduating than at any point in our history. We're proud of all of you. Congratulations::: class of 2020! You did it!  https://bddy.me/2YWrRrd  RIT.EDU Record number of RIT students to graduate
